The main reason our customers love us is because the theme has been built with them in mind. This is the theme you want if you are looking for unlimited possibilities.[/vc_column_text][vc_single_image image="9415" img_size="full" css=".vc_custom_1526199653053{margin-bottom: 40px !important;}"][vc_custom_heading text="Illustration In Marketing Materials" font_container="tag:h2|font_size:34px|text_align:left|line_height:1.5em" use_theme_fonts="yes" css=".vc_custom_1526073788517{margin-bottom: 20px !important;}"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1526073677232{margin-bottom: 40px !important;}"]If you are applying for a job abroad (particularly in Europe or South America), a Motivation Letter For Work Abroad takes the place of a Cover Letter. Both resumes and Motivation Letters are much less formal than their United States equivalents. The Motivation Letter, as its name implies, tells your prospective employers why you are motivated to work for their companies. It gives you a chance to describe your personality, the languages you speak, any awards you may have won, and what motivates you to work abroad.

The Motivation Letter is constructed like a formal business letter, with your name and address in the top right corner. Beneath this and against the left margin should be the name, job title, company and address of the recipient. (It is worth doing a little digging to find out the name, if you don’t know it.) European countries don’t put a period after title abbreviations, so remember to leave them off ; i.e., “Mr” instead of “Mr.” and “Dr” rather than “Dr.”. Spell out the name of the month and use the order “day-month-year.” [/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1526073755537{margin-bottom: 40px !important;}"]

You can customize anything you see directly from the front-end, see the changes you make live and you don't need to code anything to do it.

[/vc_column_text][vc_single_image image="9415" img_size="full" css=".vc_custom_1526199682404{margin-bottom: 40px !important;}"][vc_custom_heading text="Creative Outdoor Ads" font_container="tag:h3|font_size:28px|text_align:left|line_height:1.29em" use_theme_fonts="yes" css=".vc_custom_1526073828890{margin-bottom: 18px !important;}"][vc_column_text css=".vc_custom_1526074493636{margin-bottom: 18px !important;}"]If you are applying for a job abroad (particularly in Europe or South America), a Motivation Letter For Work Abroad takes the place of a Cover Letter. Both resumes and Motivation Letters are much less formal than their United States equivalents. The Motivation Letter, as its name implies, tells your prospective employers why you are motivated to work for their companies. It gives you a chance to describe your personality, the languages you speak, any awards you may have won, and what motivates you to work abroad.

The Motivation Letter is constructed like a formal business letter, with your name and address in the top right corner. Beneath this and against the left margin should be the name, job title, company and address of the recipient. (It is worth doing a little digging to find out the name, if you don’t know it.) European countries don’t put a period after title abbreviations, so remember to leave them off ; i.e., “Mr” instead of “Mr.” and “Dr” rather than “Dr.”. Spell out the name of the month and use the order “day-month-year.”[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text]
